p: The growth of the phytopathogenic fungus A. alternata was affected by eight out of the ten compounds tested, since β-caryophyllene and (−)-β-pinene were totally ineffective. (+)-camphor was the most effective compound, showing an inhibition activity higher than copper sulphate, while the antifungal activity of (−)-camphor and (−)-verbenone was instead comparable to that of the fungicide. (+)/(−)-borneol also determined a strong inhibition of the fungal growth ( Figure 5). Rosmarinic acid, the only phenolic compound tested, showed a partial inhibiting activity against A. alternata. The fungus produced a diffusible dark-brown pigment in response to the presence of rosmarinic acid in the medium, as shown in Figure S1 of the Supplementary Materials.
